lines.content: This is a project template for a greenfield Java project. It's named after the Java mascot _Duke_. Given below are instructions on how to use it.
Prerequisites: JDK 17, update Intellij to the most recent version.
1. Open Intellij (if you are not in the welcome screen, click `File` > `Close Project` to close the existing project first)
1. Open the project into Intellij as follows:
1. Select the project directory, and click `OK`.
1. If there are any further prompts, accept the defaults.
1. Configure the project to use **JDK 17** (not other versions) as explained in [here](https://www.jetbrains.com/help/idea/sdk.html#set-up-jdk).
In the same dialog, set the **Project language level** field to the `SDK default` option.

3. After that, locate the `src/main/java/Bot.Duke.java` file, right-click it, and choose `Run Bot.Duke.main()` (if the code editor is showing compile errors, try restarting the IDE). If the setup is correct, you should see something like the below as the output:
implementation group: 'org.openjfx', name: 'javafx-base', version: javaFxVersion, classifier: 'win'
implementation group: 'org.openjfx', name: 'javafx-base', version: javaFxVersion, classifier: 'mac'

Responsible for providing methods for formatting user input date string into readable date string format
* Converts the given date string to a readable format. It determines if the
* input is in a datetime format or a date-only format and applies the appropriate conversion.
* @param input The date string to be converted.
* @return The formatted date string or an error message if the format is invalid.
* Checks if the input string is in the "d/M/yyyy HHmm" datetime format.
* @param input The date string to be checked.
* @return true if the input matches the datetime format, false otherwise.
* Checks if the input string is in the "yyyy-MM-dd" date format.
* @param input The date string to be checked.
* @return true if the input matches the date format, false otherwise.
* Converts a date string in the "d/M/yyyy HHmm" format to a more readable format.
* @param input The datetime string to be converted.
* @return The formatted date string with a day suffix and time.
DateTimeFormatter outputFormatter = DateTimeFormatter.ofPattern("MMMM yyyy, h:mm a");
* Converts a date string in yyyy-MM-dd format into a more readable string format
* @param input The date string to be converted.
* @return The formatted date string in "MMM dd yyyy" format.
* Adds the appropriate suffix to a given day of the month (e.g., "1st", "2nd").
* @param day The day of the month.
* @return The day with its corresponding suffix.
* The Duke class serves as the main entry point for the bot application.
* It handles user interaction, file management, and task management by using other classes.
* The class initializes the necessary managers and the parser to process commands.
private final ListManager dukeManager = new ListManager();
private final FileManager dukeFileManager = new FileManager("src/main/java/data");
private final Parser parser = new Parser(dukeManager, dukeFileManager);
System.out.println("Bye! Hope to see you again.");
* Greets the user and starts processing commands in a loop.
* Reads any existing data from the file first and continues to interact
* with the user until an exit command is issued.

* Reads the content of the file located at filePath.
* If the file does not exist, it creates a new file.
assert this.filePath != null && !this.filePath.isEmpty() : "File path must not be null or empty";
* Writes the specified text to the file. This method appends the text to the file,
* ensuring that existing content is not overwritten. Every item added will end with a line break (to a new line)
* @param textToAdd The text to be added to the file.
// File to write to will always exist as will call readFile method first always on boot up which would automatically

assert textToAdd != null : "Text to add must not be null";
System.out.println("IOException encountered when writing to file!");
* The ListManager class manages a collection of tasks, allowing for creation, listing,
* updating, and deletion of tasks. It uses an ArrayList to store the tasks and provides
* methods for interacting with this list.
* Method that takes in a string and returns all tasks that includes that string. Can be used
* to list all items by just passing in a "" argument
* Sets the completion status of a task at the specified index.
* @param done  The completion status to set (true for done, false for not done).
* @param index The index of the task in the itemList (1-based index).
public void setDone(boolean done, int index) {
* Retrieves the string representation of the task at the specified index.
* @param index The index of the task to retrieve (1-based index. We will handle it to be 0-based in this method with a -1).
* @return The string representation of the task, or an empty string if the index is invalid.
assert index >= 0:"Index for getItem is negative!";
* The Parser class is responsible for interpreting user commands and invoking
* the appropriate methods to handle tasks such as creating, marking, unmarking,
* deleting, and listing tasks. It interacts with the ListManager to manage the tasks
* and FileManager to handle file operations.
* Enumeration representing the types of tasks that can be handled by the Parser.
* Parses the user's command and calls the appropriate method to handle it.
assert command != null && !command.trim().isEmpty() : "Command cannot be null or empty";
* Handles the "mark" and "unmark" commands to mark or unmark tasks as done.
* @param command The full input string from the user.
* @param action  The action to perform ("mark" or "unmark").
private void handleMarkUnmark(String command, String action) {
assert action.equals("mark") || action.equals("unmark") : "Action must be 'mark' or 'unmark'";
if (taskNumber == -1) return;  // parseTaskNumber returns -1 if invalid command given
String statusMessage = isMarking ? "Nice! I've marked this task as done:\n" : "OK, I've marked this task as not done yet:\n";
System.out.println("Invalid command format. Please use the correct format.");
System.out.println("You didn't type a valid number.");
